pageContext.analysis: Research indicates that scare advertisements about drugs are not effective. Between 1998 and 2004, the U.S. government spent nearly $1 billion on a national campaign designed to discourage young people from using illegal drugs, particularly marijuana. A 2008 follow-up study funded by the National Institutes of Health found the campaign “had no favorable effects on youths’ behavior” and may actually have prompted some to experiment with drugs — an unintended “boomerang” effect, the Associated Press reported.
